stem: The nurse is assessing clients with heart failure. For each finding, select whether it is primarily a consequence of Left-Sided Heart Failure or Right-Sided Heart Failure. Each finding may indicate more than one condition.

rows.text: Jugular venous distension (JVD) and peripheral edema.
Audible crackles (rales) in the lung bases.

rationale.correct: Heart failure symptoms result from the specific side of volume backup. (r1 & r4) Left failure backs blood into the lungs, causing pulmonary symptoms (Crackles, PND). (r2 & r3) Right failure backs blood into the systemic circulation, causing venous distension, liver congestion, and edema. (r5) Fatigue is a systemic consequence of low forward flow common to both sides (though often originating on the left).
rationale.incorrect: Isolated right-sided failure (Cor Pulmonale) does not typically cause pulmonary edema/crackles unless left heart involvement exists.
clinicalPearls: The most common cause of right-sided heart failure is actually chronic left-sided heart failure.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'L' for Lungs (Left failure) and 'R' for Rest-of-body (Right failure).

reviewUnits.heading: Heart Failure Pathophysiology
reviewUnits.body: Left-sided failure involves systolic or diastolic dysfunction of the left ventricle. Right-sided failure often results from pulmonary hypertension or left heart disease. Key nursing goal: Preload and afterload reduction.
